question: 別れる
sourceMnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an <ja>う</ja> sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>separate</kanji>, so you can guess the meaning is <vocabulary>to separate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be divided</vocabulary>.
sourceReadingMnemonic: Remember the word <ja>分ける</ja>? That word means "to separate" too. The reading is similar, though not the same, but we can at least use it as a jumping off point. We go from <ja>わける</ja> to <ja>わかれる</ja>. It's like we've "separated" the <ja>け</ja> and the <ja>る</ja> and combined them in the middle. <ja>け</ja>, making a <ja>かれ</ja>, which gets you to <ja><reading>わかれる</reading></ja>.
